hello black hat welcome to the president's cup cyber competition finding the best cyber talent the
federal government i'm harry mortoz i'm an advisor to the executive assistant director for cyber security at the cyber
security infrastructure security agency at the department of homeland security and this is i'm matt carr i'm the
project lead for president's cop from the software engineering institute at carnegie mellon university where i also
serve as an adjunct instructor at the information networking institute
so let's talk about the president's cup this came about as a result of executive order 13870
the america's cyber workforce executive order and it tasked the department of homeland security with developing a plan
in 90 days to run a cyber security competition to identify challenge and reward the
best cyber talent federal government by the end of december by december 31st 2019.
the competition was to include 10 different functional areas that would be tested there was to be a team and individual
component of the competition which would be open to federal civilian employees as well as
uniformed service members although it did task us with developing a plan to identify ways to include
non-federal participants as either observers or competitors
it also tasked us with uh identifying ways to incentivize agencies to uh identify their best cyber talent to
participate uh for this competition especially given the short timelines we were only able to announce the competition uh three weeks
before we launched our first qualifying round we knew we had to open it up as wide as possible
so our criteria for running this competition it had to be as accessible as possible uh it had to have minimum hardware
software requirements to allow really anyone to participate especially given we're targeting federal employees who may be participating
during work hours we don't want them downloading a bunch of vulnerable vms to hack away at on their on their federal
equipment and it had to be able to be done remotely particularly the qualifying rounds in order to get down to
the finalists so with those criteria in mind we developed our plan
to do two qualifying rounds that would be completely remote ending in a final
round that would be uh in person and we would put a unique twist on that which we'll talk about a
little bit later uh the down selects for the qualifiers were based on performance uh in in the rounds for the individual
competition it was the top hundred individuals and anyone who tied for that hundredth place
was invited to participate in round two for the teams uh it was the top twenty percent of teams who performed in round
one would be invited to participate in round two as well as the best teams from each cfo act agency
so that was the plan and we were able to put this together submit it to the white house at the end of july and in early
august we were given we were given the go to uh to move forward and execute our plan
we knew we had to hit the ground running we only had four months at that point to complete the competition
we were able to get our first qualifier up in 45 days matt do you want to talk a little bit about that
yeah thanks harry uh i it was uh a whirlwind effort there to develop out a platform uh that was
capable of hosting over a thousand individuals uh and teams and putting
them through an online qualification round and so what we ended up doing was
leaning on some software that we already had that was already being used to develop training and exercises known as topomojo
and pairing it with a new software development known as gameboard uh new software app that would uh kind of take
those labs and put them together into a competition uh format so you know with
points and leaderboards etc uh so back to toba mojo we have uh this application
that's used to build really you know kind of small labs uh for uh training
and uh and uh exercise purposes so if you need to run somebody through a uh
introduction to it to a cyber security tool or to some kind of uh uh scenario
then this is a good tool for that it's now open source up on github and we used it because we saw this as a good model
for creating a challenge because we wanted the same kind of scope for each of our challenges
and we also wanted one of the benefits of tokomojo is it's very fast to get these environments deployed and we
didn't want to have as you already mentioned people downloading large vms and having to run them on their own gear so instead we
hosted all these challenges and you were just a click button click away from deploying
them having access to consoles and ultimately using those consoles to virtual machines to solve the challenge
based on the scenario that's provided in the write-up so they may be small virtual environments but we were able to create
some really interesting challenges there one of my favorites from the first year is called build the road where
competitors were initially given access to one virtual machine just just the regular user vm and they
had to find a firewall on the subnet that they initially connected to they had to properly configure that firewall
in order to be able to see an intrusion detection system and ids on the other side which they then had to
properly configure in order to be able to see a router on the on the far side of that which they
had to properly configure in order to get to a vm on the far side which allowed us to really explore some
creative challenge development techniques which ultimately met the needs of the
executive order which tasked us with those 10 functional areas that we were to test which included uh some cyber
defensive uh roles and and tasks that are not very commonly seen in a lot of
uh a lot of ctfs and and uh cyber competitions but this platform really enabled us to dig into that and uh
execute that on a broader scale yeah and just to add on to that we also got feedback during the development
phase that uh we wanted uh we you know we would need to have downloadable challenges as much as possible and so
many of the challenges that we uh that we built uh did have downloadable uh
portions to them and uh those challenges you could still solve on your own system it usually involves some kind of
artifact uh that was benign what would uh walk you through that process and the
same artifact was then available and hosted in the hosted topo mojo environment well it also allowed us to deploy the
variants uh do you want to talk a little bit about our infinity challenge yeah so so first up we uh we wanted to make sure
that uh that that each challenge had more than one answer there were multiple variants deployed uh potentially
deployed for each challenge we had at least four variants for every uh president's cup challenge in year one
and that was just used so that if uh you know two people were uh working through
uh the game board that they wouldn't necessarily uh get the exact same answers for those challenges um we also
uh we also have a technology that you uh talked about uh called infinity style
challenges which allow uh procedural generation of the correct answer as the challenge is deployed and that just
means that instead of there being four variants there's now infinite variance of that challenge and no two
deployed challenges would necessarily have the same correct answers and that really helps us we hope to improve upon
that and build more of that into future presidents cups because we think that is a novel way to deliver challenges that
we know that you arrived at that answer through your own work yeah
uh that first year was a really interesting experience one of the uh design choices that we made for the
competition in order to make it as as open and accessible as possible while
creating as level of playing field as we could was the use of the participation timer so
the round one was open for 10 days competitors could log in at their convenience at any point 24 by 7
during that 10-day period and attempt challenges one of the things that we needed to be very mindful of especially
given our audience of fully employed federal employees and military service members was we had to
be mindful of the time that we were asking of them to participate we want to make sure that those who had more time to invest
in this would not get an advantage over those who maybe had a limited amount of time to try it
so for that first year we implemented an eight-hour timer where uh at any point during those ten days you could log in
and you would start the game board and when you started the game board you would get an eight-hour timer that
would count down that would be your participation time or at the end of the eight hours you wouldn't be able to submit any additional flags or
receive any additional points yeah and i'd say that was something even as we were just going through the
development of the first round for the 2019 president's cup that
was a new thought to me i i was accustomed to just a normal
longer window and people having an opportunity to compete during that entire time but i do think this worked
out certainly the best for the president's cup audience and we've even gotten feedback from other
competitions where they're trying to do uh down selects and find uh the best folks that this is a a good way to go
about it because then you don't advantage folks that do have more time or able to take a week off work or
whatever that is so we found as we started interviewing some of our competitors in year two
that this actually factored into their strategies and how they approached the challenges uh
all of our teams most of our teams that were very successful that we talked to all had the same point of knowing when
to cut and run from a challenge and avoid sinking any more time into it if you only have eight hours to solve as
many uh as many challenges as you can which was interesting to hear and speaking of the timing
one of the things that was very interesting was to see how that affected challenge development and our challenge development principles
just being mindful of that limited amount of time the qualifiers the first year round one there were 15 challenges
on the board for round two there were 11. we had one challenge that we dubbed
double jeopardy because we thought it was the hardest challenge in the competition to date it involved tasking
a competitor with pulling a flag out of an encoded stream that they were given a
packet capture for they had to identify the stream identify the type of encoding play the traffic back in order to
extract the flag and uh the average solve time was six hours for this challenge one of our teams solved it in
15 minutes so this raised a ton of red flags we manually review all of the submissions
at the end of each round and this raised some eyebrows so we reached out to the team uh to confirm
that this was a legitimate solve and they gave us a write-up for how they how they approached the challenge and how they solved it and it was it was legit
uh very impressive which just just goes to show that one of the things that we kept finding
over and over is no matter how much time you put into developing a challenge there will be a competitor who will find
a new or novel way to solve it yeah absolutely and we spent a lot of time uh qa testing
challenges we actually had support from uh pacific northwest national labs and argonne national labs uh to help us uh
look at all the challenges and and figure out uh you know where we think these uh challenges might break down and
where where we need to kind of beef up uh what's in the challenge but even with all that you know there are there are
certain there's no uh there's nothing like putting it in front of all the talented uh competitors in the
president's cup and seeing what they'll do with it yeah i couldn't agree more which actually leads nicely into the finals uh
so that first year of the finals was just such an interesting experience
uh putting all of this together so we held the final round in person uh in 2019
actually here at our cyber lab in arlington virginia and uh we brought the top 10 individuals
and the top five teams of each of five participants and uh sat them down and and put them
through a series of challenges so day one was the individuals and then days two and three were the teams competitions which we'll get to
momentarily uh the individuals we gave them ten challenges we gave them eight hours sat down and uh and had at it and
our winner was actually a an air force academy cadet which uh we were all very impressed i mean
what a what a story he he's a you know fantastic cyber professional and we certainly wish him the best uh
certainly a little bit surprising uh to to to see that but you know he was he
was the best so he's pretty great yeah he actually got a shout out when he graduated from the air force academy uh
the next year he got a shout out from the vice president who was uh leaving the commencement at uh at that
graduation and it's a pretty cool story so so for the teams competition uh it was
broken down into two days the first day was more challenges we had ten unique novel challenges for
them in day one they had eight hours to solve them and then day two
we took a bit different of an approach we built a cyber escape room
which sort of combined physical spatial challenges with cyber security problems
and task the teams with trying to escape in eight hours by using their their
teamwork skills their cyber security talent and uh you know their their uh
cleverness to find their way out and uh that was that was quite the stressful experience yeah absolutely we
had a great time uh building the uh uh that environment uh we partnered with
another group on campus known as the entertainment technology center or etc and they helped us put together uh this
novel uh unity-based immersive environment kind of like a video game uh coupled with cyber challenges and so we
tested we want to make sure that the video game aspect of this did not
you know dominate what we would put together so we tested it a number of times with different groups of folks
internally to make sure that they could solve that without any cyber skills at all and it always took around the same
amount of time and so it was roughly it was less than 30 minutes it would take you to get through the escape room part
of this knowing no no cyber at all and so then it just became a
cyber as the cyber challenges are what got the teams apart as far as
determining who won and who didn't win um but it turns out that that day was
pretty nerve-wracking uh because not only we were trying something new but because after four
hours the teams were not as far along in solving the escape room as we thought they would be so we had some discussions
on how we wanted to move forward and we already had you know the possibility of them we had already thought about the
possibility of nobody escaping but we certainly didn't like the the look of it you know that we had this
we tried to put together something new and we really wanted to have some teams escape and it turns out we did we did
have a team escape at the end and and another one that was hot on their heels that maybe another 15 20 minutes they
probably would have made it out as well uh one of the really interesting things that that allowed us to do with the
escape room is in keeping with the intent of the executive order and the need to
include non-federal participation as spectators or as participants we live
streamed the entire final day of the competition we got two of
my colleagues at sizza to narrate adam brown and bobby thompson who did a fantastic job
providing color commentary we were able to pull up the the screens of the competitors on the live stream and adam
and bobby were able to talk about the tools they were using how they were approaching the challenges uh and the
various techniques and what those tools are used for um it was fantastic they didn't they did an
incredible job it's still up on youtube if you search president's cup cyber uh it'll it'll pop right up um but it was
it was really really interesting to be a part of yeah i think it would it really brought what we were doing here to a
much wider audience and uh did so for a cyber competition where it is difficult
to create content to about cyber competitions that's engaging
for that period of time and so they did a great job of uh explaining what was going on in a given scene what was going
on in a given scenario and what tools were in use how you would use those tools in real life how they apply to
this specific scenario and ultimately uh provide a lot of uh detail that uh
wouldn't have come if it weren't for them and their their efforts that day but we were able to put together that
live stream using another team from uh the sei the broadcast media team uh that
was in the room right next door the control room and they uh were kind of feeding through headsets what to
pay attention to what we're going to what they're going to switch the the monitors to and we actually switched
between everybody's view of the president's cup uh environment so all the teams were on systems that were
deployed around this facility and we were switching them live onto the live stream as we needed to demonstrate a
specific technique or what was going on or certainly towards the end when the excitement was happening and they're about to escape
yeah it was it was really special to be a part of it was um really an interesting experience
but as it turns out there's there's you know no rest for the weary so immediately after concluding president's
cup year one we started looking ahead at year two what do we do to improve the competition where do we take it from here
for starters we had a lot more time to prepare in year two which we were grateful for but we started right away
we knew we had to get started we knew we had to build something compelling to follow up we took a hard look at year one we
looked at what worked for us we looked at what didn't work uh we're extremely grateful to our competitors uh there was a group that
put together a really thoughtful aar that uh we reviewed we we got a ton of
feedback from a bunch of our competitors that we looked at and you know it actually led to a lot of
positive change in the competition led to the development of partial credit challenges do you want to talk about that yeah so for year one uh partial
credit challenges were intermixed with with some of the other uh single
answer challenges and you just use some kind of delimiter to uh within what you were inputting into the
challenge every challenge had a single field where you put your answer in but some of our challenge developers would
use delimiters in order to say oh concatenate all these different things and put them into a single submission um
but the problem with that is if you got any one part of that wrong uh you got the answer wrong you only had three
strikes and you're out on any of the challenges and so you might not find out why you
got it wrong because it could have been just one of these parts and so that understandably led to
competitors wanting to have something to show for spending over an hour involved in a challenge and that's where we
developed partial credit which just uses a percentage of you know the overall points applies
it to each diff one of the different parts and then you also know as you're submitting what you've gotten right and
not right so it allows you to then focus on the area of the challenge that you
still have wrong in hopes of correcting that before you run out of time yeah absolutely it also led to some
format changes so we took a different approach with the individual competition for year two uh eight hours is a long
block of time for uh somebody to be participating in an individual competition so we took it down to four
hours and we broke it into two separate tracks as well to be mindful of specialty areas within cyber security so
track a focused on incident response and forensics track b focused on exploitation analysis vulnerability
assessment and we did this uh in part uh because we didn't we were
surprised at the overlap in the end when we saw who was qualifying for the final round in fact
there were 20 slots for the final round 10 in each uh individual track and we
wound up with 15 competitors because that's how many how that's how much overlap was yeah half of each track

that number of our competitors who uh are have talent in both areas and are able

and and the operating conditions surrounding government uh the competition was entirely remote for the

a couple months ago we wrapped president's cup 2 we had to do it completely remote
